entry.title: nasin pi lipu nimi
entry.content:
A thought experiment: how might one use a toki pona reference document which only uses sitelen sitelen?

Hereâ€™s an explaration: sin la, nasin sitelen pi lipu nimi

sona (background info)

sitelen sitelen is one of the many orthographies of toki pona.

It is a beautiful and creative writing system! But its inherent flexibility can be challenging to navigate.

As a beginner to toki pona who was fascinated by sitelen sitelen, I was looking for many source documents to see how different people drew the glyphs. I then found myself wanting a method of defining a glyph based on its visual appearance, not knowing its pronunciation, and with only a rough understanding of the sitelen sitelen alphabet (or even the languageâ€™s vocabulary).

This reminded me of studying Mandarin, and using Chinese dictionaries organized by radical and stroke count â€” and I wondered if something similar (but also pona!) were possible for sitelen sitelenâ€¦

nasin (method)

There are 26 â€œrootsâ€ (visual components);
The roots are in a particular order;
Each glyph has a unique set roots associated with it;
Each glyph is sorted according to its root-order.

This allows a dictionary user to quickly locate an unrecognized glyph within an arbitrarily-sized list of otherwise â€œdifficult-to-orderâ€ glyphs, with only a rough understanding of the roots and ordering necessary, and without depending on any knowledge of pronunciation (of either the glyph or the sitelen sitelen â€œalphabetâ€).

  • The most significant aspect of the glyph is designated the primary root. All glyphs have a primary root.
    • The â€œmost significantâ€ aspect could be the center or the largest portion of the glyph, or a unique symbol compared to the remainder of the glyph.
    • The primary root will determine the broad location of the glyph.
  • Remaining aspects of the glyph may be designated additional roots.
    • Additional roots are not necessary (i.e. some glyphs have a primary root and no additional roots);
    • These tend to follow a pattern of â€œnext most significantâ€, with allowances so that glyph sequences are unique.
    • The sequence of additional roots will determine the fine-grained location of the glyph.

wan mute (roots)

My goal is to have the â€œrootsâ€ be roughly from simple-to-complex, and to use the established sitelen sitelen phoneme glyphs as a starting point.

The five vowel â€œinfixesâ€ are prominent in many of the full glyphs, so Iâ€™ve chosen to use them as the very beginning. The order is roughly: mouth; basic eye; complex eye/s; full face.

The nine consonant â€œbasesâ€ are next, in this rough order: dots; wrinkles; bumps; different structures.

The above fourteen phoneme glyphs donâ€™t quite cover all the existing full glyphs, so Iâ€™ve identified some more shapes (drawing from existing sitelen pona glyphs) as common roots. These are ordered from simple/geometric to complex/anatomical.

Last but not least, two â€œmetaâ€ roots, notable for how theyâ€™re placed in relation to other self-contained glyphs: the â€œcartoucheâ€ container shape; and the â€œplinthâ€ supportive-base shape.

The specific roots and order are still subject to change.

entry.title: how to consistently pay back dependency tech-debt in an Agile environment

link.title: how to consistently pay back dependency tech-debt in an Agile environment

entry.content:
tldr: make a â€˜recursiveâ€™ ticket which you continually schedule for future sprintsâ€¦ Product will hate it initially, but will love it eventually

Givenâ€¦

  • Software which is in-use needs to be maintained.
  • Ignoring maintenance often has little short-term pain and frees up some time but compounds over the long-term, resulting in a specific form of tech-debt.
  • No matter the management style (Agile, etc), the Product owners and/or the businessâ€™s immediate needs are regularly prioritized, despite well-meaning attempts to â€œpay backâ€ the tech-debt.

Here is a way to be able to account for necessary-but-ineffable software maintenance in a management style which demands prioritization, thereby allowing the tech team to gradually and regularly pay down tech debt:

the Sisyphus Ticket

The ticket is titled â€œUpgrade or refactor some dependenciesâ€, or something intentionally slightly vague â€” This is to allow the developer some leeway in deciding what sorts of dependency work theyâ€™ll tackle, each time the ticket rolls around.

The ticket is scheduled for a regularly-occurring specific time period â€” sprint, month, whatever the team is already using â€” This time period should be regular enough that the ticket doesnâ€™t feel unusual, but not so frequent that it gets in the way of other work.

This ticket is actually many tickets, which are created recursively â€” part of the Acceptance Criteria is to create a new ticket, ready to be scheduled/refined â€” This ensures that the pattern continues!

After seeing several dependency-laden codebases (using e.g. NodeJS, or Ruby on Rails) become brittle as their developers are not able to upgrade the scaffolding of the application, and witnessing the same pattern happen with different leaders and team members and management styles and team structures, I was looking for a way to have the Product team(s) recognize the notion of â€œexpected maintenanceâ€. In order for it to be useful in a variety of situations, the form of this expected maintenance has to fit however the Product team wants to manage, so in my case it took the form of a never-ending series of Jira tickets.

Normally a developer would hate the idea of an infinite sequence of tickets, but this is essentially free time for the developer to tackle whatever tech debt they see fit to tackle. I like to have these tickets rotate between the developers, so that everyone gets a chance to scratch whatever itch was bothering them lately.

Really, this dripping tap of work is an accurate reflection of maintenance costs and should scare the Product team more than anyone else! Itâ€™s the cost of doing business with any codebase, no matter how many dependencies there are â€” there should always be periodic maintenance, to clear out the cobwebs and grease the wheels and upgrade the latches.

This pattern has been successful for two years and counting, on a high-importance internal project which therefore has lots of Product and Leadership attention (and therefore is more likely to have techdebt de-prioritized!), allowing the team to keep all but two (!) dependencies on the major version (in a modern NodeJS project with extensive unit and integration tests).
entry.summary: tldr: make a â€˜recursiveâ€™ ticket which you continually schedule for future sprintsâ€¦ Product will hate it initially, but will love it eventually

NodeJS v16.17 / v18 introduced a new module named node:test which includes basic test scaffolding! This makes it real easy to whip up a super-basic JS test file and iterate on it, without having to set up a framework like Mocha or Jest.

Save this to a file named with a .mjs extension, e.g. test.mjs:

entry.title: creating a new Git repo based on the history of an old one

link.title: creating a new Git repo based on the history of an old one

entry.content:
Following this how-to by Nassos Michasâ€¦

tldr:

  • create a new blank repo, e.g. via GitHub ux
  • git clone --mirror old-repo-URL new-repo-name note URL of old repo, but name of new one
  • change remote to URL of new repo: cd new-repo-name && git remote set-url origin new-repo-URL
  • git push this will take a while, and may show errorsâ€¦
  • cd .. && rm -rf ./new-repo-name because we need to clone it fresh (not as a mirror)â€¦
  • git clone new-repo-URL && cd new-repo-name the clone may take a while

The new repo on GitHub will need to have its default branch set.

entry.title: npm ci with legacy-peer-deps is a thing

link.title: npm ci with legacy-peer-deps is a thing

entry.content:
So youâ€™ve got a JavaScript project in the wild, and real life happens so youâ€™ve been npm installing with the --legacy-peer-deps for a little while now. No judgement, weâ€™ve all been there.

Then you upgrade something, and all your tests run fine locally, but in the CI environment the entire test suite is faceplanting immediatelyâ€¦ What gives??

Turns out that the npm ci command (which iirc exists in order to use the exact versions laid out in the package-lock.json file ğŸ˜’ ) will also need to be passed the --legacy-peer-deps flag if youâ€™ve used that flag to create the lockfile.

This is written down (if not explained) in the docs for the ci command: source, emphasis in the originalâ€¦

NOTE: If you create your package-lock.json file by running npm install with flags that can affect the shape of your dependency tree, such as --legacy-peer-deps or --install-links, you must provide the same flags to npm ci or you are likely to encounter errors.

This appears to have been introduced in NPM v8.6 according to this bug report.
